##World Health Organization says new pneumonia is not yet a global epidemic. How will other countries respond?

I-CAIJING

CAIJING magazine official Wechat. "CAIJING" magazine, sponsored by the China Securities Market Research Center, was first published in 1998, adhering to the news concept of "independence, exclusiveness and originality" , and is known for authoritative, impartial and professional reporting, it is a must-read publication for policy-makers, researchers and managers in the field of politics and economics.

Restrictions on entry may do more harm than good, as they may impede the flow of information, medical supplies and affect the world economy; although no confirmed cases have been found in Africa, medical experts expect that, the risk of an outbreak in Africa is not small

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
By Cai Tingyi, CAIJING correspondent

Editor | Hao Zhou

GENEVA, Feb. 4 afternoon, the World Health Organization (WHO) said that the COVID-19 pneumonia epidemic has not yet constituted a "global epidemic, " at the same time, World Health Organization director-general Tan Desai appealed to member states, share information about the new coronavirus outbreak with World Health Organization in a timely manner and refrain from restrictions that are inconsistent with the IHR.

"Right now, 99 percent of the confirmed cases [ globally ] are still in China, and 97 percent of the deaths are in [ China's ] Hubei Province, so this is still the number one emergency in China, " Tan said. Who is working closely with the Chinese government. "This is our best way to stop the global spread of the epidemic. "

On the same day, the Foreign Office advised all about 30,000 British citizens living in China to leave the country and will send more special planes to take them this week. As of press time, the British government has dispatched two special planes to arrive in Britain on January 31 and February 2, respectively, a total of 94 British citizens and their families have been taken to RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire, north-west London, for 14 days of isolation and medical observation at Arrow Park Hospital in Wirral.

"The room was very comfortable, we got a bag with all kinds of important supplies, even underwear, " Rove Raw, who originally lived in Wuhan, said in a video recording his life in isolation in Britain. He was quarantined with his mother and Chinese wife.

Although the United States, Australia, New Zealand and other countries have imposed temporary restrictions on visitors from China, the Department of Health says it has no plans to stop them. More than 40 countries, including the United Kingdom, Germany, France, Poland and Canada, only carry out temperature tests and epidemic screening at entry points. Some countries require Chinese citizens to complete health declaration forms.

The global response remains inadequate

Since the end of January, several countries have sent planes to help their nationals leave Wuhan, and the world has faced the test of how to prevent the COVID-19 from evolving into a global outbreak. In its 13th, 14th and 15th reports, the World Health Organization Organization noted that "in the past 24 hours, no new cases of infection have been reported in any country. ".

"There's a lot we don't know about this virus, " epidemiologist, who taught at Harvard for many years, told CAIJING, "The epidemic it causes is constantly changing... It is spreading and cases are increasing very rapidly... we haven't seen this virus for a long time. "

To speed up doctors'efforts to identify possible symptoms, World Health Organization said Feb. 5 that some minor symptoms, such as a runny nose, sore throat, cough and fever, could be symptoms of COVID-19 infection, in some people the symptoms may be more severe and may lead to pneumonia or difficulty breathing. The WHO will convene a global meeting of experts next week to identify priorities for research into the current outbreak and call for accelerated global co-operation in developing reagents, drugs and vaccines to bring it under control.

"The virus is so contagious that there is little doubt that it will be a pandemic, but will it be catastrophic? I don't know, " said Foutch Anthony Fauci, director of National Allergy and Institute of Medical Science.

Speaking at a meeting of the WHO's executive board on February 3, COVID-19 warned again that the virus could spread to new countries as quickly as the flu, but that the global community's lack of preparedness was a danger. A few days ago, the World Health Organization Organization declared the COVID-19 outbreak a "public health emergency of international concern" , "Our biggest concern is the spread of the virus to countries where health systems are relatively fragile and where preparedness is inadequate. "

As of Feb. 4, a total of 159 cases of COVID-19 infection had been confirmed in 23 countries and regions outside mainland China. The highest number of cases was in Japan, with 20, followed by 19 in Thailand and 15 in South Korea. The rate of death in these cases is not high. On Feb. 1, the Philippines reported its first death outside China, a 44-year-old man from Wuhan. Hong Kong, China -- The first death occurred Feb. 4 in a 39 year old man who visited Wuhan.

"The case-fatality rate of confirmed cases is 2.1 percent, " according to the current statistics of cases in China, and 3.1 percent in Wuhan, the epicenter of the outbreak, China's National Health Commission said at a news conference on Feb. 4. The fatality rate of SARS in 2003 was about 15% .

The spread of COVID-19 in parts of China continues. On February 4, South Korea confirmed a case of infection in a woman who had travelled to Thailand. On February 5, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced that 10 people aboard the Diamond Princess, a cruise ship based in Port of Yokohama, had been confirmed to have been infected with coronavirus. This brings the total number of Japanese infected to 33, not ruling out the possibility of dozens of infected people on board. In addition, a Belgian woman on Britain's second expat charter flight tested positive for the virus upon her arrival in the UK, while other passengers on the same flight are being quarantined and put under medical observation.

Experts at the University of Southampton, which monitors the movement of mobile phone numbers to create a model of population movements, say the world's most likely cities are Bangkok, Hong Kong and Taipei. By country, Thailand and Japan were the two most at risk, with the United States in sixth place.

The epidemiologist prefers to stage the next stage of the virus's spread in order to prevent the spread of the virus. The US should prepare for a possible outbreak with a "virus is here" mentality, including mobilising hospitals and speeding up arrangements for virus detection and isolation, leading US outbreak experts said.

Some scientists also pointed out that countries in the fight against the epidemic can not respond to the response, now is the time to take further long-term planning. Johns Hopkins University Professor Tom Inglesby said the effectiveness of the U.S. government's efforts to close borders and isolate patients needed to be reassessed, "because once other countries have community-based infections, does the United States also require quarantine of nationals returning to the United States from those countries? If there is a pandemic, we need to look at every possible measure, assess whether it works and what the social costs might be."

Forced evacuation and necessary isolation

Mcavoy matthew L McCoy, 55, is a theme park designer whose new identity is U.S. flight 211 out of Wuhan. After mcavoy and the other Americans were lucky enough to get on a plane home but were told they couldn't go home immediately, he and the other evacuees were placed in a 14-day quarantine at the Mudgee military Base in southern California, it was the first federal quarantine measure in the United States since 1963.

"We are provided with professional and high-quality care by our disease control staff and consular staff, who check us several times a day, " mcavoy told Caijing.

On isolated military bases, everyone is housed in separate rooms, where they can communicate with each other, and even some sports and art professionals offer classes for others who are also in isolation. During the Super Bowl in the United States on February 3, the quarantines also held a viewing party.

These treatments are not free. With a $1,000 last-minute plane seat and 14 days of isolation without work, mcaway recently launched a crowdfunding campaign asking people to help him make up for his financial losses.

In addition to the United States, Japan, South Korea, India, Bangladesh, Indonesia, Turkey, the United Kingdom, France, Australia, New Zealand, Germany, Russia and Malaysia are among those taking similar measures.

The choice of quarantine facilities and the coordination of all expatriates with the implementation of quarantine are not easy. Like the United States, Germany chose to quarantine its air bases; Britain requisitioned the National Care Staff Building; and the Australian government chose Christmas Island, a small island used to keep out illegal immigrants, even though it would pay for the evacuation, the first expats evacuated to the island criticized the area as "crawling with cockroaches and weak Internet signals, " with some complaining that the food supply was not ideal.

Faced with another coronavirus in 2015, the Middle East outbreak called Mers, South Korea had a number of infected patients who went out to parties without actually being quarantined. The South Korean government has also opted for a mass quarantine of more than 700 expatriates, with large numbers of disgruntled locals in the cities of Asan and Jincheon where the two quarantine sites were chosen. Hundreds of police have also been deployed in response to possible large protests to prevent attacks on the Diaspora.

When the Japanese government quarantined 565 evacuees from the National Institute of Public Health of Japan in Saitama Prefecture and the city of Hikari, there were suicides by officials who carried out the evacuation. The Chief Cabinet Secretary announced on February 4 that the quarantine would be changed to self-management, and cut the quarantine from 14 days to 10.

The French government chose the isolated spot, the Carry-le-Rouet in the South West, which is the envy of expatriates in many other countries. The Carry-le-Rouet faces the Mediterranean Sea, and apart from taking their temperature twice a day, the quarantined expats are free to walk outdoors, play volleyball, play football and take art classes. The site was chosen by the French government, which pointed out that winter was a low season, and residents of nearby villages objected at one point, but a compromise was reached.

In addition to quarantine, some countries (such as the United States, Singapore and Australia) have banned foreign nationals who have been to China in the hope of keeping the virus out; Japan has narrowed the scope, foreigners who have stayed in Hubei Province for less than 14 days before applying for entry, and holders of Chinese passports issued by Hubei Province, are temporarily prohibited from entering the country. Russia, Pakistan and Italy have also done the same. There is no answer as to whether these countries are doing the right thing, but they are clearly at odds with World Health Organization's recommendations.

Southeast Asian countries, where Chinese tourists are the most frequent visitors, are much more cautious than European and American countries. The Philippines has taken steps to reduce flights rather than cancel them altogether. Thai Airways has canceled flights to some cities, but other flights are normal. Cambodia's Prime Minister, Hun Sen, tried to calm fears by holding a news conference in which he chose not to wear a mask and said he would "kick out people who wear masks" , because it creates an atmosphere of unfounded fear.

Announcing that the outbreak constituted a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC) on 31 January, the World Health Organization said that restrictions on entry could do more harm than good because they could block the flow of information and medical supplies, impact on the world economy. Who also recommends that there is no need to restrict the entry of foreign citizens, but only to carry out screening at the border. At the Feb. 3 meeting, Tandser also reiterated that countries should invest more in preparedness rather than "panic. ".

Temporary immunity in Africa is not promising

One of the few areas where cases have not occurred since the outbreak is in Africa, where infectious diseases are frequent. Several African countries, including Ethiopia, Kenya, Angola, and Ivory Coast, have reported cases that turned out to be false alarms. But infectious disease experts are not optimistic about Africa's temporary immunity.

"We are very concerned about Africa because some of the most unprepared countries are in Africa, " said Thomas Frieden, a former director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. "African countries are more deficient than other places in identifying the virus and preventing its spread. "

Ambrose Otau Talisuna, a doctor at World Health Organization's Africa office, also noted that the risk of an outbreak in Africa was "very, very high. "

WHO, after listing the outbreak as PHEIC, accelerated preparedness in Africa, listing 13 countries as high-risk, including Uganda, Kenya, Nigeria, South Africa, Congo and Ethiopia. These countries have installed temperature monitoring equipment at airports while creating space that could be used for isolation. The Gates Foundation also announced at the end of January a $10 million donation to the COVID-19, half to China and half to the African Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

The sooner these countries can detect the virus, the sooner they can contain the epidemic and avoid overburdening the health system, said World Health Organization's Africa director, Matshidiso Moeti. However, there are only two laboratories in Africa with testing capacity, so one of World Health Organization's main tasks in helping to prevent epidemics in Africa is to help countries improve laboratory equipment and distribute testing kits to more than 20 countries.

In order to prevent the epidemic, some countries began to take active measures. The Nigerian government encourages travellers arriving from China to quarantine themselves for at least two weeks without any symptoms, while Mozambique currently suspends the issuance of visas to Chinese citizens, as well as Chinese passport holders; The government of South Africa quickly established an emergency response centre to stop postal parcel operations and began monitoring at 36 entry points.

Gason, director of the African Center for Disease Control and Prevention, is concerned that there are cases on the continent that have yet to be discovered, despite the accelerated deployment of preventive measures in many countries, because he hasn't seen an epidemic that changes so quickly.

The global epidemic is not over, how to quickly detect suspicious cases is becoming the focus of attention of epidemiologists. The nucleic acid test kit, which is widely relied on in China, is considered too time-consuming by many foreign experts, and its accuracy will decline when the number of tests is too large.

Epidemiologist told Caijing that it is a problem to pick out suspicious cases for testing when there is an increase in suspicious cases, such as in the United States, if the criteria is people who have close contact with the Chinese, how about a Chinese restaurant?

With the COVID-19 still poorly understood and its transmission and mortality rates still uncertain, the epidemiologist said people should prepare for the worst and avoid underreaction. Professor Gregory Poland, an epidemiologist and vaccine expert at Meilhaud, advised the world to treat the epidemic as if it had entered a "pandemic" state, don't forget "SARS is controlled by very low-tech but effective methods, including washing hands, wearing masks and social distance, which is what we should focus on in the future. "

Read more about the outbreak in pictures
